questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the office with a 3-day history of sharp neck pain that began during a long car drive. Medical history is remarkable for breast cancer metastatic to the bone. Physical examination reveals C4 restriction to right translation that worsens in extension and tenderness on palpation of the right cervical paraspinal muscles. You decide to employ facilitated positional release (FPR) to address the somatic dysfunction. You slightly flex the patient's cervical spine and apply a compressive force on the head. The next step of FPR involves positioning the C4 segment in

choices.text: neutral with right rotation and right sidebending
extension with left rotation and right sidebending
extension with left rotation and left sidebending
flexion with right rotation and right sidebending
flexion with right rotation and left sidebending

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has a C4 FRRSR dysfunction. While positioning the patient's C4 segment in right rotation and right sidebending is part of FPR and may induce release, her restriction to extension is not addressed in the neutral position.

B) INCORRECT:

Rotation and sidebending occur to the same side in the inferior division of the cervical spine (C2–C7); rotating and sidebending to opposite sides is, therefore, not consistent with FPR.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has a C4 FRRSR dysfunction. Extension with left rotation and left sidebending, therefore, moves the dysfunctional segment towards its restrictive barrier. This positioning is done in direct treatment methods (e.g., high-velocity low-amplitude techniques), which are typically avoided in patients with metastatic bone disease.

D) CORRECT:

In indirect treatment methods such as FPR, which are gentler and suitable for patients who are at increased risk for pathologic fractures (e.g., due to metastatic bone disease), the focus is on moving tissues and/or joints away from the restrictive barrier (i.e., into the position of ease) to enhance joint function and alleviate tissue tension. In FPR, the dysfunctional segment is first brought to a neutral position (e.g., slight flexion of the cervical spine); an activating force such as compression or torsion is then introduced. The segment is subsequently moved into its position of ease, which in this case is flexion with right rotation and right sidebending. The position is held for 3–5 seconds before being released.

The treatment sequence of FPR can be remembered as "neutral, compress, ease."

E) INCORRECT:

Rotation and sidebending occur to the same side in the inferior division of the cervical spine (C2–C7); rotating and sidebending to opposite sides is, therefore, not consistent with FPR.
questions.hint: Right translation (osteopathy) of the cervical spine produces left sidebending. Since sidebending and rotation occur to the same side in segments C2–C7, a C4 restriction to right translation that worsens in extension suggests that the segment is flexed, rotated right, and sidebent right (C4 FRRSR).

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of intermittent neck pain. He also reports occasional dizziness. On questioning, the patient denies any trauma. He works as a software engineer and spends most days working on his laptop. Past medical history reveals type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. He does not smoke cigarettes and drinks 3 beers on weekends. Vital signs reveal:


Temperature
36.8°C (98.2°F)


Blood pressure
141/92 mm Hg


Heart rate
82/min


Respiratory rate
16/min


C2 translation from right to left is restricted when the neck is extended. Neurological examination reveals no abnormalities. The physician considers osteopathic manipulative treatment using high velocity, low amplitude (HVLA) to correct the patient's cervical somatic dysfunction. Before proceeding with HVLA, it is most appropriate to perform which of the following diagnostic tests?

choices.text: Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry
Wallenberg test
Spurling test
Adson test
Extension and flexion cervical x-ray

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA scan) is used to evaluate patients with suspected osteoporosis or screen for osteoporosis. Severe osteoporosis is a contraindication for high velocity, low amplitude treatment because of the increased risk of fractures. In patients with no other risk factors, a DXA scan is recommended for women at 65 years of age. However, there is currently no recommendation to screen for osteoporosis in men. In addition, this patient does not have significant risk factors (e.g., corticosteroid use, history of heavy drinking) or previous history (e.g., bone fracture following minor trauma) to suggest osteoporosis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is at risk for vertebrobasilar insufficiency, which is a contraindication for high velocity, low amplitude (HVLA) treatment. To evaluate for this condition, Wallenberg test is used, in which the patient's neck is flexed and extended in the supine position for 10 seconds each, followed by the same for the head and neck rotated to both sides. The test is positive and suggests vertebrobasilar insufficiency if the patient develops symptoms such as increased dizziness, lightheadedness, nystagmus, or visual changes during the test. This test should be performed before applying HVLA to the neck or any technique that mobilizes the cervical spine.

Other contraindications for HVLA treatment of the cervical spine include rheumatoid arthritis, Down syndrome, and severe cervical disk herniation with radiculopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Spurling test is used to evaluate for cervical nerve root compression, which may also manifest with neck pain and can occur in patients with work-related neck strain. Cervical disk herniation with radiculopathy can be exacerbated by HVLA treatment. However, this patient does not have radicular pain or any sensory or motor deficits that suggest cervical nerve root compression. This patient is at greater risk for another condition that warrants a different test.

D) INCORRECT:

Adson test is performed to evaluate for thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), which can also manifest with neck pain. However, TOS is mainly characterized by paresthesias occurring on the palmar and dorsal surfaces along the medial side of the hand, the 5th finger, and the ulnar side of the 4th finger (ulnar nerve distribution), which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Extension and flexion x-rays of the cervical spine are used to evaluate for atlantoaxial subluxation in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which is a contraindication for high velocity, low amplitude treatment because of joint instability and the risk of atlantoaxial subluxation. This patient does not have any clinical findings suggestive of RA and is at greater risk for another condition that warrants a different test.
questions.hint: Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension increase this patient's risk for vascular complications. In addition, erectile dysfunction can be an early indicator of underlying cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the office with a 3-week history of left arm pain and tingling in her left thumb and index finger. She also reports occasional neck and left shoulder pain. She first noticed her symptoms after spending a day at home working in her garden. The patient denies any trauma. Past medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. She requests osteopathic manipulative treatment to improve her symptoms. Vital signs are normal. Cervical range of motion is moderately limited in all directions. Range of motion in the upper extremities is normal bilaterally. Biceps and brachioradialis deep tendon reflexes are decreased on the left. Which of the following maneuvers is most appropriate to evaluate for the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Raising the left arm above the head then hyperabducting and extending the arm
Flexing the neck and holding for 10 seconds, then extending the neck and holding for 10 seconds
Abducting, extending, and externally rotating the left arm and turning the head toward the left arm
Extending, sidebending, and rotating the neck to the left while applying downward pressure to the head
Reaching behind the head with the left hand to touch the opposite shoulder

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This maneuver, known as the Wright test, is used to assess for thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). The test is positive if the patient's radial pulse disappears during the maneuver. Although TOS can manifest with neck, shoulder, and arm pain, paresthesias occur along the palmar and dorsal aspect of the medial side of the hand, the little finger, and the ulnar side of the ring finger (ulnar nerve) rather than the left thumb and index finger.

B) INCORRECT:

This maneuver, known as the vertebral artery test or Wallenberg test, is used to evaluate for vertebrobasilar insufficiency. This test can also be performed with passive cervical rotation to the right and left with the neck in extension. The test is positive if the patient experiences dizziness, visual changes, lightheadedness, and/or nystagmus. The Wallenberg test is often used before performing any type of cervical spine manipulation. This test should be especially considered in patients with risk factors for vertebrobasilar insufficiency, such as atherosclerosis. The Wallenberg test is not used to evaluate for cervical nerve root compression.

C) INCORRECT:

This maneuver, known as the Adson test, is performed to evaluate for thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). The test is positive if the patient's radial pulse decreases while in this position. Although TOS can manifest with neck, shoulder, and arm pain, paresthesias occur along the palmar and dorsal aspect of the medial side of the hand, the little finger, and the ulnar side of the ring finger (ulnar nerve) rather than the left thumb and index finger.

D) CORRECT:

This maneuver, known as the Spurling test, is used to evaluate for cervical nerve root compression. The Spurling test narrows the affected foramina and compresses the cervical spine. The test is positive if the maneuver exacerbates or reproduces the patient's radicular symptoms (e.g., neck and left arm pain, left thumb and index finger paresthesias).

When applying osteopathic manipulative treatment to patients with cervical radiculopathy, it is essential to employ gentle techniques and avoid high-velocity low-amplitude (HVLA) manipulations, particularly when severe neurological deficits or spinal instability are present.

E) INCORRECT:

This maneuver, known as the Apley scratch test, evaluates the range of motion in the shoulder and is typically used to detect conditions such as rotator cuff tears and adhesive capsulitis. Although it is appropriate to evaluate the range of motion in the shoulder in patients with shoulder pain, this patient's symptoms are consistent with cervical root compression, making a different maneuver more appropriate.
questions.hint: The patient's arm pain and paresthesias in her thumb and index finger, combined with decreased biceps and brachioradialis reflexes, suggest C6 radiculopathy, most likely from a C5–C6 spinal disk herniation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the office because of a 2-day history of neck pain that began after a long tennis match. He denies any numbness or tingling. Physical examination is negative for neurological deficits, and C4 demonstrates resistance to right translation that improves when bending the head backward. The most likely somatic dysfunction at C4 is

choices.text: flexed, sidebent left, rotated left
flexed, sidebent right, rotated left
flexed, sidebent left, rotated right
extended, sidebent right, rotated right
extended, sidebent left, rotated left
extended, sidebent left, rotated right

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flexion with left sidebending and left rotation describes the direction of this patient's restricted motion. However, somatic dysfunctions are named based on freedom of motion. This diagnosis would be correct if examination had revealed restriction in left translation (osteopathy) that improves in flexion.

B) INCORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction for C2–C7. Therefore, this diagnosis is inconsistent with osteopathic principles.

C) INCORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction for C2–C7. Therefore, this diagnosis is inconsistent with osteopathic principles.

D) CORRECT:

Restriction in right translation (osteopathy) suggests that left sidebending is restricted. Sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction for C2–C7, indicating restricted left rotation. Since the restriction improves in extension (i.e., bending the head backward) and somatic dysfunctions are named based on freedom of motion, C4 extension with right sidebending and right rotation (C4 ESRRR) is the correct diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

C4 extended, sidebent left, rotated left would be the correct diagnosis if examination had revealed restriction in left translation (osteopathy) that improves in extension. This patient's restriction in right translation (osteopathy) implies restricted left rather than right sidebending.

F) INCORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction for C2–C7. Therefore, this diagnosis is inconsistent with osteopathic principles.
questions.hint: Lateral translation (osteopathy) of the lower cervical spine induces sidebending to the opposite side.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the office because of a 2-day history of neck pain that began after a long tennis match. He denies any numbness or tingling. Physical examination is negative for neurological deficits, and C4 demonstrates resistance to right translation that improves when bending the head backward. The patient consents to osteopathic manipulative treatment using Still technique. To treat this patient's C4 somatic dysfunction with Still technique, C4 is initially positioned in

choices.text: extension with left sidebending and left rotation
extension with right sidebending and right rotation
extension with left sidebending and right rotation
flexion with right sidebending and left rotation
flexion with left sidebending and right rotation
flexion with left sidebending and left rotation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although improved movement during extension (i.e., while bending the head backward) indicates freedom of motion, this patient's C4 is restricted in right translation (osteopathy), indicating that left sidebending and left rotation are restricted. Therefore, another initial position is more appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's restriction in right translation (osteopathy) indicates that left sidebending is restricted. Sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction for C2–C7 indicating restricted left rotation. Improved translation in extension (i.e., while bending the head backward) indicates freedom of motion in that position. Therefore, the direction of ease in this patient is C4 extension with right sidebending and right rotation. The next steps in Still technique are to apply compressive force and maintain compression while moving the segment toward its restrictive barrier.

C) INCORRECT:

Because rotation and sidebending occur to the same side for C2–C7, Still technique for C4 does not involve rotation and sidebending to opposite sides.

D) INCORRECT:

Because rotation and sidebending occur to the same side for C2–C7, Still technique for C4 does not involve rotation and sidebending to opposite sides.

E) INCORRECT:

Because rotation and sidebending occur to the same side for C2–C7, Still technique for C4 does not involve rotation and sidebending to opposite sides.

F) INCORRECT:

Flexion with left sidebending and left rotation is the direction of restriction in this patient. Although moving the dysfunctional segment into its restrictive barrier is a part of Still technique, this is not the correct initial position.
questions.hint: Still technique is a passive treatment that involves initially positioning the dysfunctional segment in the direction of ease.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of neck pain. Questioning reveals she spent several hours painting the ceilings in her home over the past few days. Physical examination reveals C5 restriction in left translation that improves when moving the chin toward the chest. Neurologic examination is normal. Treatment of this patient's somatic dysfunction with direct muscle energy requires initial positioning of C5 in

choices.text: extension with right sidebending and right rotation
flexion with left sidebending and left rotation
extension with left sidebending and left rotation
flexion with left sidebending and right rotation
flexion with right sidebending and left rotation
extension with right sidebending and left rotation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Restriction in left translation (osteopathy) indicates that right sidebending is restricted. Sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction for C2–C7, which means that right rotation of C5 is restricted in this patient. Furthermore, the improvement in flexion when this patient moves her chin toward her chest indicates restricted extension in C5. Because direct muscle energy involves positioning the affected vertebra toward its restrictive barrier, extension with right sidebending and right rotation is the correct initial position to treat this patient's somatic dysfunction.

Since somatic dysfunctions are named based on freedom of motion, this patient's diagnosis is C5 flexed, rotated left, sidebent left (C5 FRLSL).

B) INCORRECT:

Flexion with left sidebending and left rotation describes this patient's direction of ease. Indirect treatment methods, such as counterstrain and facilitated positional release, involve initially positioning the affected tissues and/or joints away from the restrictive barrier (toward the patient's direction of ease).

C) INCORRECT:

Restriction in left translation (osteopathy) indicates that left sidebending and left rotation are the patient's direction of ease. Furthermore, the improvement in flexion when this patient moves her chin toward her chest indicates restricted extension in C5. Muscle energy is a direct technique, which involves initially positioning the segment toward the restrictive barrier, rather than toward the direction of ease.

D) INCORRECT:

Rotation and sidebending occur to the same side for C2–C7. Therefore, muscle energy does not involve rotating and sidebending C5 in opposite directions.

E) INCORRECT:

Rotation and sidebending occur to the same side for C2–C7. Therefore, muscle energy does not involve rotating and sidebending C5 to opposite directions.

F) INCORRECT:

Rotation and sidebending occur to the same side for C2–C7. Therefore, muscle energy does not involve rotating and sidebending C5 in opposite directions.
questions.hint: As a direct technique, muscle energy treatment involves initially moving the affected vertebra toward the restrictive barrier.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the office with persistent headaches and neck stiffness for the past 2 weeks. He reports that the headaches are primarily located at the base of the skull. He denies any recent trauma or falls but mentions having recently picked up wood carving as a hobby. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. Physical examination reveals limited range of motion in the neck and palpation elicits tenderness at the occiput. The occipitoatlantal (OA) joint is asymmetrical with restriction in left translation that worsens in extension. Treatment with high velocity, low amplitude (HVLA) involves applying which of the following movements?

choices.text: Flexion of the OA joint prior to thrust
Flexion thrust toward the sternum
Rotational thrust toward the right shoulder
Translational thrust toward the left eye
Left sidebending and right rotation of the OA joint prior to thrust

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In HVLA, the affected body part is first positioned to engage the restrictive barrier before a quick thrust is applied. Then, a quick thrust is applied to force the dysfunction further into and through the restrictive barrier. Flexion would move the affected OA joint toward its position of ease.

B) INCORRECT:

In HVLA, the affected body part is first positioned to engage the restrictive barrier. Then, a quick thrust is applied to force the dysfunction further into and through the restrictive barrier. Flexion would move the affected OA joint toward its position of ease.

C) INCORRECT:

To perform HVLA for cervical segments C2–C7, a sidebending or rotational thrust directed toward the contralateral side (e.g., the opposite shoulder for a sidebending thrust) can be applied. HVLA does not involve a thrust directed toward the position of ease, which includes right rotation in this patient's OA dysfunction (OA FRRSL). Moreover, HVLA treatment of an OA joint dysfunction involves a thrust directed toward the eye rather than the shoulder.

D) CORRECT:

To perform HVLA, the restrictive barrier must first be engaged. In flexed, rotated right, sidebent left OA dysfunctions, this requires positioning the OA joint into left rotation and right sidebending (i.e., left translation). The physician's thrusting hand is then placed on the base of the occiput. Then, a lateral thrust is applied toward the contralateral eye (in this patient the left eye), resulting in translation of the OA joint through the restrictive barrier.

E) INCORRECT:

In HVLA, the affected body part is first positioned to engage the restrictive barrier. Then, a quick thrust is applied to force the dysfunction further into and through the restrictive barrier. Left sidebending and right rotation would move the OA joint toward its position of ease.
questions.hint: Restriction in left translation (osteopathy) indicates that right sidebending is restricted. As sidebending and rotation occur in opposite directions at the OA joint, and somatic dysfunctions are named based on their freedom of motion, this patient's diagnosis is OA flexed, rotated right, and sidebent left (OA FRRSL).

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the office with a 2-day history of severe neck pain. She reports that the pain started after a sudden twist in her neck when reaching for an object on a high shelf. Past medical history reveals hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She works as a librarian and often performs tasks involving overhead reaching. She drinks 1 glass of wine per week and denies tobacco use. Her body mass index is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals C6 restriction in left rotation that improves when bending the head backward. To treat this patient's somatic dysfunction with high velocity, low amplitude (HVLA) technique, the physician should

choices.text: apply a sidebending thrust directed toward the contralateral shoulder
position C6 into left translation before applying a thrust
position C5-C6 into extension before applying a thrust
ask the patient to flex the neck before applying a thrust
apply a rotational thrust directed toward the ipsilateral eye

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

To perform HVLA, the restrictive barrier must first be engaged, which is followed by a quick thrust over a short distance to move the somatic dysfunction through its restrictive barrier. HVLA treatment of cervical segments C2–C7 can involve a sidebending or rotational thrust. To treat a somatic dysfunction at C6 using HVLA, the physician can apply a sidebending thrust directed toward the contralateral shoulder. In this patient, the restrictive barrier is engaged by positioning the C6 segment into left rotation and left sidebending (i.e., right translation). Then, a sidebending thrust is applied by translating the C6 segment further to the right and through the restrictive barrier.

B) INCORRECT:

During HVLA, the patient is initially positioned toward the restrictive barrier and relaxes while the physician performs the technique (direct and passive). As this patient has a C6 ERRSR dysfunction, positioning C6 into left translation (i.e., right sidebending) would not engage the restrictive barrier.

C) INCORRECT:

During HVLA, the patient is positioned toward the restrictive barrier and relaxes while the physician performs the technique (direct and passive). This patient's somatic dysfunction improves when the head is bent backward (i.e., extension). Positioning C5-C6 into extension would not engage the restrictive barrier.

D) INCORRECT:

During HVLA, the patient is initially positioned toward the restrictive barrier and relaxes while the physician performs the technique (direct and passive). Therefore, the physician, not the patient, should flex the patient's neck to the appropriate level.

E) INCORRECT:

To treat a cervical somatic dysfunction below the C1 segment using HVLA, the physician can apply a rotational or sidebending thrust toward the contralateral, not ipsilateral, side (e.g., a rotational thrust directed toward the contralateral eye).
questions.hint: In C2–C7, sidebending and rotation occur in the same direction. As somatic dysfunctions are named for their freedom of motion, this patient's diagnosis is C6 extended, rotated right, sidebent right (C6 ERRSR).
